captions.text:
As far as we know, around 4,500 million years
ago this rock that we live on coalesced from

the dust and debris left over from the formation
of our sun. Without airplanes, pizza delivery,

or the Internet, things moved more slowly
across the early earth than they do today.

For example, from isolated puddles of water,
the oceans formed over the course of 400 to

800 million years. That's how long it would
take for your hair to grow around the earth

- twice. In that same time, bacterial life
did spread across the watery globe. Higher

plants and animals, on the other hand, took
much longer to develop and disperse. But we're

going to skip those 3 billion years (during
which your hair would have grown to the moon)

and talk about us, Homo sapiens. We were much
faster than our own hair, which would have

grown a meager 27km in the 180,000 years we
took to cross Africa and reach all the unfrozen
continents.

In many of these places we were able to develop
useful practices like agriculture, but because

we were scattered across the globe, the best
ideas and tastiest regional foods could only

gain ground through trade or human migration.
Wheat, for example, was domesticated around

8500BC to make porridge. Actually, some speculate
it might have been for beer, but either way

wheat made it from the Fertile Crescent to
both the Atlantic and the Pacific by roughly

6000km in 6000 years might seem like a blistering
pace, but just wait for the Middle Ages! The

bubonic plague and the printing press each
spread across Europe in less than a hundred

years, bringing death and literacy to the
populace before their hair could have even

grown 15 meters. In the 20th century, mania
for both the Beatles and the Hula hoop raced

around the world in a year or two. Now even
a year is a long time. With millions of people

jetsetting across the globe every day, diseases
such as SARS can vacation almost anywhere

within a few short weeks. And the 0s and 1s
that make up this video take, on average,

less than a tenth of a second to get to you
- that's about half a nanometer, or two atoms,
of hair growth.

In short - the pace of travel on earth has
really sped up!

But how do we know this stuff? How do we know
what happened on earth before the records

of written history? Why do we think the earth
is 4,500,000,000 years old? And what on earth
is going to happen in the next 45 years?

Welcome to the story of what we know about
the earth and how we know that we know it.
This is MinuteEarth.

title: MinuteEarth: The Story of Our Planet

comments.text:
I really don't get it.. I seriously don't understand why people have to 
throw their religious beliefs into this.. Why? What does it matter? You can 
believe what you will, but we're here for facts, believe it or not this is 
factual. Nothing about this video criticizes god or anything, it's about 
what we know, and from this forms the question of how we know it; basically 
to say he'll explain in later videos. This whole "Debate" on evolution is 
quite chaotic if you ask me, because there's really no debating it, it has 
more evidence than necessary to be a fact. This guy is basically explaining 
it all to us, and you all disregard it with answers of chance and god, when 
really we know most of what had happened. Surely, there are things that we 
don't know, but we won't sit back and relax saying "Well, god did it". 
That's not how science works, it studies, evaluates, and explains what IS. 
So as for your religious beliefs, you may keep them, just keep them to 
yourself, because we've examined our minds and understand so far that 
there's nothing that can't be explained while disregarding creation. If you 
don't already know, science began as the observation of what god had 
created, later, those early scientists began to disregard a creator because 
of it, and this doesn't just include evolution or the big bang, it includes 
all of science, and even then science doesn't prove or disprove a creator, 
creation is unfalsifiable, can't be proven nor disproven, and that's why it 
is left out of scientific studies, and after all of that, people still 
accept science and believe in a creator, scientists who study evolution 
have religious people within their studies, and same with many other 
branches of science. It's all an opinion.﻿

improbable.  If you'd like further evidence Harold Morowitz of Yale 
estimated the probability of evolution to be 1 in 10 to the 340,000,000 
power.  He is currently a professor of biology and natural philosophy at 
George Mason University

comments.author: thegreeenbeast

comments.text:
+thegreeenbeast that has to be the stupidest metaphor I've read in a long 
time. Let me put it to you this way. You've been duped into believing that 
science knows exactly how everything was made. The facts are that science 
has no idea how the universe was made, much less how life was made. You 
blindly accept theories as fact, when they are not fact. I will admit that 
most Christians have no idea what is going on either. The simple truth is 
neither you, nor I has any evidence to prove to the other our beliefs. Make 
no mistake your religion is evolution. Your belief is that with a big bang 
and a whole lot of luck this universe and all the life in it just appeared. 
Your belief system is no different than mine. You're just to ignorant to 
admit that everything you think you know is based on some guys unproven 
theory. You really need to ask yourself how much of this is just plain 
bullshit and how much isn't. Most of evolution is total horseshit backed up 
by bullshit. There is evidence of any kind linking humans to apes, none. 
Then there are the paracas skulls, which have 0 DNA markers for anything 
terrestrial. Skeletons of humanoid creatures with no ties to anything 
earthly. How the Fuck does evolution explain that?!? You can't, but they 
are real and have been DNA tested, look it up. You being a dick and 
thinking you know it all just proves how little you really know. I'd 
continue but this conversation bores me. Have a nice life, not that a dick 
like you deserves it.
comments.author: Michael Nichols

comments.text:
+Michael Nichols
Why people who believe in actual science are often such douches towards 
religious people?
Let me put it like this: imagine you learned all your life to repair cars. 
Then someone comes along who knows nothing about it and says "No, you are 
wrong, cars run on ping-pong balls, not gasoline. That is my opinion, but 
most evidence points towards this. No you are wrong. Have a nice day".
Is it right to be douchie towards that person? Maybe not, but i can 
guarantee you its fucking annoying and its really tempting.

comments.text:
+Michael Nichols
The world HAS to be mathematically perfect. If we took another random world 
with fixed laws of physics that world would ALSO be mathematically perfect 
according to their math. If a universe isnt mathematically perfect it is a 
universe without any form of logic. And though that may be possible, we 
live in a world with logic. An automatic consequence of that is that its 
math works out.
As for Einstein, he did not believe in a god as described in the bible or 
any other religion. He believed there MIGHT be a creator (he was an 
agnost), but not one that interferes with life.
But then again you have to remember that einstein was far from perfect. He 
has made some significant mistakes. Now CERN as an organisation hasnt found 
anything that actively supports the idea of a god. There exists NO proof 
that a god exists. There is just no way to disprove his existence that is 
all. So "but the proof is undeniable" is either ignorant or a plain lie.

it grows when we need it cut. It's more about the representation than the 
factual appropriation
comments.author: QuinnRileyMitchell

comments.text:
+enderman Slender I mean this:
 Hair on every part of your body grows to a certain length and then falls 
out. On most of your body the natural length is a few millimetres to a few 
centimetres. But on your head the natural length is about 80 cm. So the 
hairs on your head will grow until they reach 80cm, then they will fall 
out. Since you have so many hairs, only a few are falling out at any time.
The point is hair can't be that long!

comments.author: Zara B

comments.text:
Evolutionists claim that the Earth and the solar system is about 4.55 
billion years old. They believe this amount of time is necessary for all 
the life forms on earth to evolve.


One of the best ways to show that the earth is not "billions of years old" 
is to look at the sun.

We are all aware that the sun is burning. What you may not have thought of 
though, is that it can not burn forever. Though the sun does oscillate, it 
is also rapidly decreasing in size and mass.

For the last 300 years Boyal Observatory in England. They have carefully 
recorded the rate the sun is shrinking. They have determined that the sun 
is shrinking at a rate of 5 feet per hour. At this rate, the sun would have 
been twice its present radius only one million years ago. The farther you 
go back in time, the larger the sun would have been.

"The shrinkage rate centuries ago would be determined by the balance of the 
solar forces. Since the potential energy of a homogeneous spherical sun 
varies inversely with the solar radius, the rate of shrinkage would have 
been greater in the past than it is now."
This means that today’s rate of shrinkage (5 feet per hour) was faster 
years ago. Perhaps at the rate of 10 or 20 feet per hour.

The sun would have been big enough to touch the earth only 20 million years 
ago. Evolutionists claim the earth is 4 BILLION years old. You can see why 
this is Impossible.

If the earth was Billions of years old, then the earth would have been 
destroyed by the sun.

The Evolutionists idea that dinosaurs lived 65 million years ago is absurd. 
This is far too long ago for the sun to have allowed life on earth.

The earth can not be millions of years old.
﻿

comments.text:
i just saw this (sorry!) but yeah it really depends on the individual,i 
personally am not religious because i strongly believe no RELIGIOUS god is 
the right one...im open to believing that there might be a god but theres 
nothing anyone can say that tells me his name and what he wants from me is 
in religious text..they all seem almost ignorantly manmade...especially in 
the way they contradict themselves(talking about religious scripture 
btw)...belief in god isnt necessarily a bad thing the way most atheist 
would have you believe...but the problem is that when whats being presented 
doesnt fit with the belief...they try to halt progression because it doesnt 
fit with their opinion...and im sure i dont have to tell you that theres a 
huge difference between believing in something because a book said so and 
believing something because it has hundreds (sometimes thousands) of things 
that back up and support the idea..and neither one is "wrong"...but when 
something is supported by mountains of evidence and can be recreated in 
labs all over the world by many different scientists to achieve the same 
results..and then its halted because it doesnt fit with someones opinion on 
the origin of the universe...you can see where the tension comes 
from...beliefs are fine but only if you realize that theyre just 
that..beliefs...everyone needs to be open to the fact that they might be 
wrong..especially when its an admitted faith...faith by definition is 
believing without evidence so if at that point youre not open to being 
wrong youre just very close minded...but after a long winded rant back to 
the point...look at us in comparison to the known universe...then remember 
that we came from this universe in some way...whether ti was god or natural 
kinda is irrelevant for my point...but either way we are a spawn of the 
universe of course we arent going to have the answers...and our size 
compared to the universe is so tiny its on a scale so small you truly cant 
comprehend it...to think wed have a full understanding of what we came from 
when we are not even a spec of dust in comparison is to me almost 
idiotic...and the fact that it seems so complex shouldnt be proof of an 
"intelligent" designer because as i said...whether a god did it or its 
natural...WE STILL CAME FROM IT so of course its going to seem complex to 
US...for all we know all the dust and everything that makes up the universe 
did come from nothing..and maybe that isnt totally out of the 
ordinary...maybe it happens every 100 billion years...just because it seems 
amazing to us doesnt make it so...we would probably have a hard time 
recreating all the elements that make us up in a lab using hydrogen and 
helium..yet stars do it all the time....we cant crush everything into a 
singularity in a gravitational field so strong that we cant even see it 
because light cant escape yet it happens all the time..i guess my point is 
that whether its natural or whether god did it , it would still seem 
incredible and sometimes impossible to us because we are tinier then a spec 
of dust in comparison.. something like matter popping out of no where might 
seem incredible to us but thats because we havent seen it before...or maybe 
the matter was always there...my point is that there might be a totally 
normal explanation for all of it but it would seem complex to us because of 
our part in the universe...which if you were to measure the impact we had 
on the universe it would be 0...sorry for the rant but as you can see its 
hard to explain especially in text
comments.author: bunchofdumbsits youallare

comments.text:
+x goken So it wouldn't matter if, hypothetically (and I don't mean to 
offend, just using an example), the following were true?

Satan was the one trying to save humanity and the one currently called God 
was actually the one presiding over hell. As we know people say the devil 
tries to trick and deceive, it would make sense for the devil (in this 
case, 'God'), to trick millions into believing the wrong things by 
rewriting the Holy Text slowly over the course of thousands of years, 
gradually, until the entire 'truth' of the matter was completely flipped 
around so the benevolent Satan was seen as a brutal demon while the 
trickster God was seen as the path to heaven?

You said "It doesn't matter if it was re-written", but this is an example 
where I would assume it being re-written means quite a bit. It would mean 
the entire faith is currently based on lies, deceit and manipulated texts 
from centuries ago, which drastically changes the context and meaning of 
those texts.

Now, if you're saying the current message of the Bible (to be good to each 
other, don't be a dick, etc) is what remains constant, that's true, but 
that's the underlying morals of the book. The morals of the Bible don't 
equate to the stories about creation being true. The Bible is a great tool 
to teach how people should act toward each other (it does have some 
outdated issues, though), but it's not meant to be taken literally. If it 
was meant to be taken literally, it would by this point be so out of date 
and altered throughout the course of history that my above hypothetical 
could even be what it originally said, and no one can be certain that it 
was not, since the deceiver would have spend thousands of years covering up 
what really happened.
comments.author: TaliesinMyrddin

comments.author: x goken

comments.text:
But the Bible was written 2000 years ago before science really took off, 
and has been rewritten so many times throughout history. You didn't see the 
Bible being written for the first time, so how do you know what is 
currently there resembles even remotely what was originally written?

They can tell how the Earth was formed by observing, experimenting and 
logically projecting. This has expanded human knowledge exponentially in 
the past several centuries. What they say makes scientific sense and can be 
replicated, if we had the resources to do so, based on the mathematics and 
physics of the universe.

If you want to use "who saw this happening" as a way to dismiss science, 
then explain how anyone could 'know' that God create the universe and Earth 
before humans existed, that God actually appeared and had the Bible written 
despite there being, what, one witness? That anything in the Bible 
(dictated by a human) resembled what an all-powerful, unknowable, 
incomprehensible deity was trying to explain, and that the Bible in any way 
resembles what was written 2000 years ago, considering even in the current 
day, we had news stories being blown out of proportion and edited to the 
point they barely resemble what actually occurred, within the space of 
weeks.

If you want to believe in a God who created the universe, that's fine, 
that's your right, but I see no reason in trying to dismiss science based 
off what an ancient book written by man says.
comments.author: TaliesinMyrddin

comments.text:
The Earth is 4.5 Billion Years Old. The oceans formed when the glaciers 
melt. The continents are still together and they moved appart into there 
present position. The half of Florida was underwater then it dried out. 
Primates were the earliest ancestors of the humans. All humans come from 
Africa. They lose their hairs. People with white skin were blacks that got 
paler in the cold wind. Asians had slanted eyes due to high winds. The 
Bible was written in 900 B.C. The stories in the bible is a parable. People 
started to belived in God is started with Polytheism. Christianity began in 
Jerrusalem. The Gregorian Calendar is in the A.D Years. The Months are 
named by Roman gods Exept to September To December. The English language 
comes from Greek. Spanish, French, German.
